summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting a proffer interview with a former Bureau of Prisons Corrections Officer (CO) from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The interviewee provides detailed information about his work history, duties, and observations regarding contraband, security procedures, and specific incidents at the MCC, including a gun lockdown and his subsequent placement on administrative leave. The interview was conducted by SDNY prosecutors and FBI agents.

events.title: Proffer Interview of Michael Thomas
events.description: Former MCC Corrections Officer Michael Thomas is interviewed under a proffer agreement by SDNY AUSAs and FBI agents regarding his experiences and observations at MCC.

events.title: Gun Lockdown at MCC
events.description: A significant security incident at MCC where a gun was reportedly in the building, leading to a lockdown, activation of the DCT, and searches of multiple units by officers from MCC and other prisons.

events.title: Michael Thomas Placed on Administrative Leave
events.description: Following the SHU incident during the gun lockdown searches, Michael Thomas received a phone call informing him he was placed on administrative leave, with posters stating he was not allowed in the building.

events.title: Contraband Operations at MCC
events.description: The interviewee describes systemic contraband issues at MCC, including methods of smuggling (e.g., via trash, ropes through windows), common items found (shanks, cell phones, drugs), and alleged corruption schemes among staff.

locations: United States Attorney's Office, 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The interviewee, Michael Thomas, a former MCC CO, provided a proffer detailing significant security failures and contraband smuggling methods within the federal prison.

A major gun lockdown incident occurred at MCC, prompting a large-scale search involving officers from multiple facilities and leading to the interviewee's subsequent placement on administrative leave.
The interviewee alleges a 'vendetta' against him by an unnamed individual, and that he and his close colleague Tigran were targeted by rumors they passed a phone to an inmate.
Systemic contraband problems are described, including a cell with a hole and rope for smuggling, and allegations of a Cash App scheme among rookie COs to sell confiscated phones back to inmates.

The document reveals internal prison dynamics, including the dissolution of the voluntary Disturbance Control Team and other staff misconduct, such as a CO allegedly caught on camera having sex with an inmate.
